Our World in Data shas some data about poverty, child mortality, etc. This, to me, is a pretty good indicator that Pinker is pretty much correct. It seems like Kickel went through some contortions to discard data, cherry pick data and spin a narrative that was overly critical. Much of what Kickel says is not technically correct but seems to be a bit dishonest in giving context.
In particular:
* the tranche of income above $5 but below $10 did shrink from 1981 to 2000 but it seems, at least naively, that the narrative could be this is because there was a migration from the $1.90 tranch upwards that only managed to then push upwards further past 2000.
* Child mortality continues to decline
* Litteracy continues to improve
Notably, democracies hasn't been going up as fast, or at all, since around 2000.
